case_name: Workmen of the Dimakuchi tea estate represented by the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha v. Management of the Dimakuchi tea estate

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 297 of 1956 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1955, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 220 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 297 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1955, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 220 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellants are the workmen of the Dimakuchi tea estate represented by the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha, Dibrugarh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before us are the workmen of the Dimakuchi tea estate represented by the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha, Dibrugarh.

facts.text: Respondent is the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang in Assam.

facts.text: Dr. K. Banerjee was appointed assistant medical officer of the Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950, subject to satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

anchor.surface_text: One Dr. K. Banerjee was appointed assistant medical officer of the Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950. He was appointed subject to a satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

facts.text: In February 1951 Dr. Banerjee was given an increment of Rs. 5 per mensem.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1951 Dr. Banerjee was given an increment of Rs. 5 per mensem, but on April 21, Dr. Banerjee received a letter from one Mr. Booth, manager of the tea estate...

facts.text: On April 21, 1951, Dr. Banerjee received a termination letter from Mr. Booth, manager, effective from April 22, 1951, with one month's salary in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: but on April 21, Dr. Banerjee received a letter from one Mr. Booth, manager of the tea estate, in which it was stated It has been found necessary to terminate your services with effect from the 22nd instant. You will of course receive one months salary in lieu of notice.

facts.text: Reasons for termination: on the medical side, deceitful manner in which you added figures to the requirements of the last medical indent after it had been signed by Dr. Cox.

anchor.surface_text: To this Dr. Banerjee received a reply to this effect The reasons for your discharge are on the medical side, which are outside my jurisdiction, best known to Dr. Cox but a main reason is because of the deceitful manner in which you added figures...

facts.text: Manager stated Dr. Banerjee discharged on ground of incompetence in medical duties, insufficient knowledge of microscopical and laboratory work, faulty quinine injection to Mr. Peacock causing severe illness.

anchor.surface_text: The manager wrote back to say that Dr.- K. P. Banerjee was discharged on the ground 1159 of incompetence in his medical duties and the chief medical officer  Dr. Cox  had found that Dr. Banerjee was incompetent...

facts.text: Cause of Dr. Banerjee espoused by Mangaldai Circle of Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha.

anchor.surface_text: The cause of Dr. Banerjee was then espoused by the Mangaldai Circle of the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha and the secretary of that Sangha wrote to the manager...

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings held unsuccessfully over termination of Dr. Banerjee's service.

anchor.surface_text: The reasons given by the manager for the termination of the services of Dr. K. P. Banerjee did not satisfy the appellants herein and certain conciliation proceedings...

facts.text: Tripartite Appellate Board recommended reinstatement of Dr. Banerjee from date of discharge.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then referred to a Board known as the tripartite Appellate Board consisting of the Labour Commissioner, Assam, and two representatives... This Board recommended that Dr. Banerjee should be reinstated...

facts.text: Respondent offered 28 months salary and allowances in lieu of reinstatement, appellants did not agree.

anchor.surface_text: After the recommendation of the Board, the respondent herein appears to have offered a sum equal to 28 months salary and allowances in lieu of re-instatement to this, however, the appellants did not agree.

facts.text: Dr. K. P. Banerjee received Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left the tea garden.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, Dr. K. P. Banerjee received a sum of Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left the tea garden in question.

facts.text: On December 23, 1953, Government of Assam published notification referring dispute to Shri U. K. Gohain under s.10(1)(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Then, on December 23, 1953, the Government of Assam published a notification in which it was stated that whereas an industrial dispute had arisen...

facts.text: Dispute referred: Whether management justified in dismissing Dr. K. P. Banerjee, A.M.O.? If not, entitled to reinstatement or other relief?

anchor.surface_text: The dispute which was thus referred to the Tribunal was described in these terms 1160 Whether the management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate was justified in dismissing Dr. K. P. Banerjee, A. M. O.? If not, is he entitled to reinstatement...

facts.text: Tribunal (Mr. Gohain) held Dr. Banerjee not a workman, no industrial dispute, no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gohain took up as a preliminary point the question if Dr. Banerjee was a workman... Dr. Banerjee being not a workman, his case is not one of an industrial dispute...

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal affirmed that Dr. Banerjee not a workman, dispute not industrial, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: There was then an appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta. That Tribunal affirmed the finding of Mr. Gohain... The appeal was accordingly dismissed...

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on March 14, 1956, limited to whether dispute re non-workman falls within s.2(k).

anchor.surface_text: The appellants herein then moved this Court for special leave and by an order dated March 14, 1956, special leave was granted, but was limited to the question...

facts.text: Parties proceed on footing that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman within the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from what has been stated above that the 1161 question whether Dr. K. P. Banerjee is or is not a workman... we must proceed on the footing that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman...

facts.text: Supreme Court held dispute regarding termination of Dr. Banerjee's service not an industrial dispute under s.2(k), appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the appeal fails and is dismissed. In the circumstances of this case there will be no order for costs.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 4, 1958 by S.K. Das J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. February 4. The Judgment of Das, C. J., and S. K. Das J., was delivered by S. K. Das, J. Sarkar, J., delivered a separate Judgment.

concepts.interpretation: Interpreted to require community of interest; dispute must relate to person in whose employment/non-employment etc. the parties (esp. workmen) have direct or substantial interest; not any person literally.

issues.text: Whether a dispute in relation to a person who is not a workman falls within the scope of the definition of industrial dispute contained in s. 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: special leave was granted, but was limited to the question whether a dispute in relation to a person who is not a workman falls within the scope of the definition of industrial dispute contained in s. 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

issues.text: What is the true scope and effect of the definition clause in s. 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: s. 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 hereinafter referred to as the Act . The question has arisen in the following circumstances.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'any person' in s. 2(k) can include persons who are not workmen, or must be limited by community of interest or other provisions of the Act
Whether the dispute must be a real and substantial one capable of settlement, with parties having direct or substantial interest (community of interest)

arguments.claim: Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman within the meaning of the Act therefore there was no industrial dispute and the Tribunal had no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Both parties filed written statements before Mr. ohain and the respondent took the plea that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman within the meaning of the Act therefore, there was no industrial dispute in the sense in which that expression was defined in the Act and the Tribunal had no jurisdiction to make an adjudication on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gohain took up as a preliminary point the question if Dr. Banerjee was a workman... Dr. Banerjee being not a workman, his case is not one of an industrial dispute under the Industrial Disputes Act and his case is therefore beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal

arguments.claim: A dispute between the employers and employees to be an industrial dispute within s.2(k) must be between employers and workmen; cannot be between employers and non-workmen employees

anchor.surface_text: That Tribunal affirmed the finding of Mr. Gohain... A dispute between the employers and employees to be an industrial dispute within the meaning of section 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act, must be between the employers and the workmen. There cannot be any industrial dispute between the employers and the employees who are not workmen.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC accepted non-workman status but rejected strict requirement that person must be workman; instead applied community of interest test and held no industrial dispute

arguments.claim: Conditions in first and second parts of s.2(k) fulfilled: dispute between employer and workmen connected with non-employment of Dr. Banerjee even if not workman

P. Banerjee and the dispute or difference is between the employer...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: be equated with any workman , as the Tribunals below have done. The argument is that inasmuch as the dispute or difference between the employer and th

arguments.court_reasoning: Third part requires community of interest; literal reading leads to absurd results

arguments.claim: Expression 'any person' in third part of s.2(k) is of very wide import; no reasons to equate with 'any workman'; includes non-workmen like Dr. Banerjee

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants has submitted that the expression of any person occurring in the third part of the definition clause is an expression of very wide import and there are no reasons why the words any person should be equated with any workman , as the Tribunals below have done.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot mean anybody; limited by context, scheme of Act, community of interest

arguments.claim: Limitations on 'any person': (1) real/substantial dispute where relief possible; (2) relates to particular establishment; (3) person is employee/discharged/in service/candidate; (4) nexus via personal/general labour interest

anchor.surface_text: When these difficulties were pointed out to learned counsel for the appellants, he conceded that some limitations must be put on the width of the expression any person occurring in the definition clause. He formulated four such limitations...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ployee relation never existed or can never possibly exist cannot be the subject matter of a dispute between employers and workmen. Secondly, the defin

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted 1st two implicit; rejected 3rd too wide (not any employee), 4th too general; instead community of interest with workmen class

arguments.claim: S.2(k) must be read in context of Act's scheme; words harmonise with object; 'any person' limited to those with employer-employee relation possible and community of interest

anchor.surface_text: A little careful consideration will show, however, that the expression any person occuring in the third part of the definition clause cannot mean anybody and everybody in this wide world. First of all, the subject matter of dispute must relate to i employment or non-employment...

arguments.claim: Act's provisions (ss.18,33,36 etc.) show focus on workmen class; benefits only for workmen; no representation/protection for non-workmen supervisory staff

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 is important for our purpose... Section 36 which deals with representation of parties... The point to note is that there is no particular provision for the representation of a party other than a workman or an employer...

arguments.claim: Literal 'any person' leads to absurd results e.g. workmen disputing District Magistrate's salary; no community of interest

anchor.surface_text: Let us assume that... the workmen of a particular industry raise a dispute with their employer about the employment or terms of employment of the District Magistrate or District Judge... there is no possible community of interest...

arguments.claim: Crucial test is community of interest: parties (esp. workmen class) must have direct/substantial interest in the person's employment/non-employment etc.
Dr. Banerjee was supervisory/technical staff, different category from workmen; appellants (workmen) had no direct/substantial interest in his termination
'Any person' has ordinary wide meaning, includes non-workmen; precedents (Birla Bros, Western India Auto etc.) support no restriction to workmen
arguments.court_reasoning: Separate judgment by Sarkar J.; majority did not adopt

arguments.claim: No good reason to restrict 'any person' to 'workman class' or discharged/future workmen; such limitations illogical, against precedents
arguments.court_reasoning: Sarkar J. rejecting respondent's proposed limitations

arguments.claim: S.18(d) does not limit 'any person' to future workmen; its object is to bind new recruits to awards for industrial peace
arguments.court_reasoning: Sarkar J. rejecting majority's use of s.18

holdings.text: The expression 'any person' in s. 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 cannot mean anybody and everybody but is subject to limitations arising from the context, scheme, and objects of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: A little careful consideration will show, however, that the expression any person occuring in the third part of the definition clause cannot mean anybody and everybody in this wide world. First of all, the subject matter of dispute must relate to i employment or non-employment...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal interpretation leads to absurd results; words understood via harmonious construction to fit Act's object of regulating employer-workmen relations; supported by ss.18,33,36 limiting benefits/representation to workmen.

holdings.text: A real industrial dispute under s.2(k) requires: (1) real/substantial dispute capable of settlement/adjudication with relief by one party to other; (2) parties (esp. workmen class) have direct or substantial interest (community of interest) in the employment/non-employment etc. of the person concerned.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act focuses on workmen class; s.18 binds future workmen; no provision for non-workmen representation; solidarity based on community interest; distinguished Trade Unions Act; approved Chagla CJ's test.

holdings.text: The dispute regarding termination of Dr. K.P. Banerjee's service is not an industrial dispute under s.2(k) as he was not a workman but supervisory/technical staff, and appellants (workmen) had no direct or substantial community of interest therein.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of community of interest test to facts: different category from workmen; no substantial interest even if union member; affirms lower tribunals' lack of jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed as the referred dispute is not an industrial dispute within s.2(k).

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the appeal fails and is dismissed. In the circumstances of this case there will be no order for costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent to holdings h1-h3; no jurisdiction under Act.

holdings.text: The definition of 'workman' in s.2(s) (pre-1956) excludes supervisory/technical staff like Dr. Banerjee; Act distinguishes workmen from non-workmen employees.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted from lower courts and parties; proceeded on this footing; Act's scheme confers benefits only on workmen.

precedents.cited_proposition: Absurd results if 'any person' read literally without limitation, including no territorial restriction.

precedents.cited_holding: The very nature of an industrial dispute as distinguished from an individual dispute, is to obtain new industrial conditions... for the class of employees from the class of employers.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed holding that the dispute regarding termination of Dr. K.P. Banerjee's service is not an industrial dispute within s. 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 as he was not a workman and workmen had no direct or substantial interest.
